title: Thursday, 5th May, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM

Hi there

PM

A little late just cos i was trying to catch up with the latest P Green fisty-cuffs

PM

He just can't stop himself

11:01 am
PM

Throwing abuse around, threatening everyone

PM

We should maybe do a Lords and Knights of England series

PM

Looking at some of the people handed gongs over recent years

11:02 am
PM

Quite shocking really

PM

Anyway

PM

Let me get today's pic up

11:03 am
PM

PM

Yeah. Why the hell can't BT give me proper broadband given I live in London

PM

Why the hell not?

11:03 am
PM

What is the matter with them

PM

I live in an old established bit of the capital

PM

Next to a 600 year royal park

11:04 am
PM

I'm about a mile from Canary Wharf

PM

Fast broadband? Nope

BE

Why do you need fibre internet?

11:04 am
PM

Cos other people have it

BE

Okay, fair enough.

PM

All this political PR nonsense that comes out of BT

11:05 am
PM

Irritates the hell out of me

BE

Yes, sure. I'm of the opinion that no-one needs 52Mb at home, unless that person is planning to run a server farm.

BE

The Swedish (?) chap who invented DSL did us all a real favour. You can watch telly at that speed, on a copper wire put in nearly a hundred years ago.

11:08 am
BE

Yet we're still getting the roads dug up every other week, because folk think a faster link to Youtube and P***hub might fill up their lives.

BE

Frankly, I'd rather not sit on a bus for an hour in roadworks.

BE

Should we look at BT's results, since we're here?

11:08 am
PM

Guess so

PM

They make good money exploiting their monopoly, right?

BE

(@squarepeg: oh, modern gaming? Wait, I seem to have misplaced my graphene violin.)

11:09 am
PM

While hanging all their pension fund risks on the tax payer

BE

Yep, that's about the size of it.

PM

Forcing me to have a home phone that's never used

11:10 am
BE

Precisely. Worth noting that BT's relentless squeeze on line rental has been quite something.

BE

(@Airborne: Good callback! We're building a partwork here.)

BE

Let me get a Citi note from last week, when BT announced another line rental hike.

11:11 am
BE

BE

How on earth is that justified? 6% per annum since 2009!

PM

outrageous

11:12 am
BE

What's Ofcom playing at?

PM

Asleep at the wheel, i guess

PM

Ofcom are across the street from us here at FTAV HQ

11:12 am
PM

Never see much activity

BE

There are always three different but mostly overlapping Ofcom enquiries running simultaneously, grinding through laborious consultation periods ....

BE

It's like an old Soviet work-creation agency.

11:13 am
BE

Anyway! Back to today's results.

BE

They beat. Though they bet for unspecified reasons.

PM

(Thanks for trying Boncoeur -- but yes, i know)

11:14 am
BE

There's a one-off in BT Business Ireland that bumps the figures above consensus.

BE

What is it? No idea. They don't tell us.

BE

Let me get some Morgan Stanley to talk us though the headlines.

11:15 am
BE

Q4 results were ahead of expectations beating consensus estimates on
revenues by 1.6% and on EBITDA by 2.3%. The main EBITDA beat was in BT
Business. The KPIs are good with BT posting retail broadband net adds of 105k
vs 130k last quarter. Retail share of net adds at 81% from 71% the previous
quarter. Sky reported only 46k net adds. The retail fibre net adds were also
robust at 214k vs 250k the previous quarter. Normalised free cash flow of
£1,519mn was 16% ahead of consensus and driven by EE.

BE

In FY17, BT targets cash flow of £3.1-3.2bn, which compares to
consensus at £3.124bn. However, consensus and MS did not include
c£100mn due to launch of mobile handsets and c£100mn relating to the
transfer of EE integration costs from specific items into capex. Hence,
consensus FCF for comparable measures is probably c£200mn lower,
which means that the guidance implies a c5% upgrade on FCF.

In FY17, BT targets cash flow of greater than £3.6bn, which compares to
consensus at £3.124bn. Again consensus did not factor in £100mn of EE
integration costs, which have been shifted from specific items into capex.
However, on the other hand, BT benefits from c£340mn in tax, as
consensus took into account previous HMRC rules (resulting in "double"
tax in FY18), which are now not going to be implemented.

BE

Dividend growth of 10% YoY for the next 2 years is encouraging
and signals confidence in the business. We note, however, that we
were already forecasting 10% YoY dividend growth.
Synergy guidance for EE raised and integration costs reduced. BT
has raised the EE cost synergies slightly to £400m p.a (from £360m
previously). The revenue synergy guidance is unchanged at £1.6bn NPV.
BT has also reduced its EE integration cost guidance to £550m (from
£600m previously). BT expects c£100m of EE integration capex in each of
2016/17 and 2017/18.
G.Fast roll-out targets increased to 12mn homes (from 10m
previously) with investments managed within the cash flow guidance. BT
is currently trialling G.Fast technology offering speeds of 330Mbps.

11:16 am
PM

( Via Con -- that's just PR guff)

BE

(PR guff from a company that's running an unsustainable price-gouging strategy and feels the need to throw the occasional bone to a bureaucratic regulator that wastes entire years planning what it might plan to be planning.)

BE

And, Goldman.

11:17 am
PM

We don't like BT, btw

BE

4Q16 small beat, group revenue/EBITDA +2% vs. company consensus.
Guidance reassures on top line, but a small disappointment at FCF, in our
view. We note BT has historically beaten and raised guidance. Importantly,
BT has guided to top-line growth for the next two years, highlighting what
we believe is BT’s return to sustainable growth. EBITDA growth guidance
for 2017/18 is also broadly in line with consensus. Normalised FCF
guidance for 2017 at £3.1-3.2bn is c.£150mn/2% below consensus; BT notes
this incorporates an extra £100mn of EE integration costs, for which BT has
raised its annual synergy target to £400mn from £360mn (GS £410mn).
NFCF for 2018 is for greater than £3.6bn vs consensus of £3.3bn but this reflects at
least £300mn of lower tax. Underlying, we view this as broadly in line with
consensus (includes an extra £100mn of integration costs).

BE

We believe KPIs are solid, we note the impact of adverse weather in 4Q. In
the detail we note: (1) total consumer lines decreased by 18k, (vs. +6k 3Q16
-52k 2Q16, -61k 4Q15); (2) retail broadband net adds of +105k (vs. 130k
3Q16 +82k 2Q16, 121k 4Q15) represent 81% DSL market share (vs. 71%
3Q16, 49% 4Q15); (3) BT Retail fibre net adds were +214k (vs. 250k 3Q16
+212k 2Q16, +266k 4Q15); (4) BT Openreach total net adds were +415k (vs.
494k 3Q16 +415k 2Q16, +455k 4Q15); (5) TV net adds of +66k (vs. +97k
3Q16, +106k in 2Q16, +52k 4Q15). BT would be offering G.fast 300mbps+
to 10mn homes by 2020 and FTHH to a further 2mn homes. BT stated
Openreach and EE combined will spend c.£6bn in capex 2017-19 to deliver
this. We believe it may be able to accelerate its G.fast roll-out and cover
more homes over this period. We believe consensus does not reflect the
monetisation of these investments through higher ARPUs, boosting BT
revenues by over £1.5bn by 2020, on our estimates.
Implications
On our forecasts, BT offers a superior long-term growth outlook vs. peers.
BT trades on a 7.7% 2017E FCF yield vs. the sector at 7.3%.

11:18 am
BE

And, oh, Citi as well.

BE

BT has included in its guidance capex on the Emergency Services Network of up to £300m in FY17 and another £100m in FY18 and well as additional EBITDA investment in mobile handsets of £100m in FY17 and EE integration capex (included in normalised FCF). The cash tax phasing change largely explains the better than expected FCF guidance for FY18. We see both the results and the guidance (underlying) as broadly in line with expectations but see the higher target for EE savings as a positive (albeit below our estimate), as we do the plan to add 2m premises passed by FTTP to the 10m planned for G.fast by 2020.

BE

Is that enough BT? It's not that I don't like them, I just feel that they're the poster boy of how privatisation creates regulation not competition.

11:20 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 452.95, up 13.45 (+3.06%), High: 455.60, Low: 449.75, Volume: 15.60m

Did you vote this morning Bryce?

PM

11:21 am
PM

A bit of CS on the PMIs

PM

UK composite PMI fell from 53.6 to 51.9 in April, below consensus of 53.2 and lowest since April 2013.
UK services PMI fell by a point and a half to 52.3, weakest in over three years. UK manufacturing PMI fell into contraction territory, falling by a point and a half in April to 49.2, lowest since February 2013.
Overall the UK economy started Q2 on a disappointing note with weakness in all three sectors. The uncertainty of the EU referendum is cited as a reason for customers holding back on purchases, exacerbating already-weak demand linked to global growth jitters and ongoing fiscal consolidation. The national living wage is also compounding cost increases for the services sector.
The PMI surveys in April are pointing to a slowdown from 0.4%q/q in Q1 to 0.1%q/q in Q2. This survey puts PMI at a level which in the past has seen the Bank of England talk about easing. While the deterioration in data can be overlooked by the Bank of England as temporary reflecting the referendum uncertainty for the next couple of months, if we don’t see a turnaround in data post June, we can expect votes for easing.

PM

UK services PMI fell by a point and a half to 52.3, weakest in over three years and reaching its 38 month low in April. It is way below than the series average of 55.2. New business growth picked up slightly, but it still remained subdued. Business expectations fell by half a point to the joint-weakest in over three years. There was evidence that the prevailing economic uncertainty, partly linked to the forthcoming EU referendum led to clients delaying the placing of new contracts.

11:21 am
PM

Input prices rose by almost a point, to the highest since January 2014, linked to the introduction of the national living wage, rising fuel prices and the impact of the weaker pound. Service sector employment continued to expand in April, with the rate of job creation remaining above the long-run survey average. That said, the pace of growth was the weakest in over two-and-a-half years.

UK manufacturing PMI fell into contraction territory, falling by a point and a half in April to 49.2, lowest since February 2013. The fall was driven by lacklustre trends in production and new orders and declines in both employment and stocks of purchases. New orders fell also by a point and a half to 50.4, with export orders falling by roughly half a point and continuing to contract for the fourth consecutive month. Companies generally attributed the deterioration in operating conditions to a combination of softer growth of domestic demand and a reduction in new business from overseas. There were also a few reports that uncertainties regarding the oil & gas industry, retail sector and the upcoming EU referendum had led some clients to delay spending.

PM

that will do

BE

(@Airborne: as with all correlations, it works until it doesn't.)

PM

Centrica PLC (CNA:LSE): Last: 208.70, down 22.4 (-9.69%), High: 219.10, Low: 207.70, Volume: 34.32m

PM

Trying to save their credit rating, yeah?

It's just plain weird, the statement.

PM

Yeah, weird and repetitive

BE

Planning two “prioritised and attractive” acquisitions, with combined consideration of £350m

BE

I guess we'd need told if they were unprioritised and unattractive acquisitions.

11:25 am
PM

Statement here: http://www.investe...160505070000Z4816/

BE

There are two ways to read it.

PM

Goldman and UBS on this ticket

11:25 am
PM

Go on

BE

There's the idea that Centrica is sincere about this, and is buying stuff for growth.

BE

Which isn't what anyone wants from Centrica. They want a dividend and a domestic gas business that charges folk just enough to stay out of the Daily Mail for five minutes.

11:27 am
PM

Note it also repeatedly goes on about its current strong investment grade credit ratings.

BE

Yup. The other possibility is that the “challenging external environment” is actually really properly challenging and is a genuine risk to the rating.

PM

Baa1 with Moody’s and BBB+ with Standard & Poor’s.

11:27 am
BE

And the acquisition stuff's a figleaf on it.

BE

Citigroup takes the first reading, and downgrades in response.

BE

Given limited valuation upside (our new 226p TP implies a 3.2% ETR), and our concerns that the company is increasingly looking for growth through acquisitive means, which we see as a risk to the shares, we downgrade Centrica from Buy to Neutral.

11:28 am
BE

Equity placing to fund acquisitions and debt reduction.
Centrica announced its intention to raise funds via a placing of c.7% of its current share capital (c.350m shares). The company intends to use £350m of the funds raised for acceleration of Centrica’s customer facing strategy through acquisitions (including Neas and one as yet unnamed other) and £400m for debt reduction. We calculate the EPS dilution of the placing to be c.-3% excluding any benefit from earnings contribution of acquisitions, which Centrica expect to fully offset the dilutive impact on a FY basis.

BE

No longer purely a cost cutting and commodity recovery story.
While the share placing should address any remaining concerns over Centrica’s balance sheet, we believe Centrica’s appetite for growth through acquisitions is unlikely to be seen positively by the market. While Centrica management was clear that there are no other planned acquisitions on the horizon, we note that Centrica has been linked with a potential acquisition of ENI’s retail assets (source: Reuters, 28 April, 2016) and Viridian assets (source: Bloomberg, 14 January 2016) in the past. While the 8-9x EV/EBITDA multiple Centrica have stated for their announced acquisitions may be justified by the high double digit growth these assets offer, we believe the market will not give full credit for any potential value creation through acquisitive growth until we see further results. In our view, this complicates the Centrica story, which is no longer about cost cutting and recovery of commodity prices.
Insufficient valuation upside to reflect risks.
We lower our 12m SOTP-based target price to 226p from 235p and marginally adjust our EPS to reflect the £750m placing announced today, the Neas acquisition and the other acquisition indicated by management today.

BE

Let me also get Caz's notes from the conference call.

11:30 am
BE

Is £400m debt repayment enough? – The key discussion point on the call was concentrated on management’s confidence in the additional funds raised being sufficient to shore up the balance sheet at a strong investment grade credit rating (BBB+Baa1). Accordingly, by 2017 it is expected that Moody’s RCF Net Debt metric will recover by end 2017 to be comfortably above the 25% threshold. As to what level of headroom ‘comfortable’ implies, it was noted on the call that the metric would not quite be 30% by 2017, but expectations for an improvement in cash flow in the following years would most likely push the metrics higher. Certainly based on our calculations, we would need to include a significant uplift in either our operating or commodity assumptions (US$60/bbl) to get to the 30% level noted above.

BE

Dividend safe – There was some discussion around the interplay between the decision to raise rather than cut the dividend, with management electing to raise equity and therefore take a more prudent stance on managing its balance sheet in the current operating environment. We assume this implies the interim results in February, that the dividend is safe for now as guidance remains unchanged from the interim results and the £400m raised eases the near-term pressure on the balance sheet. Today’s release noted ‘the Group continues to target delivery of long-term shareholder value through returns and growth, including a progressive dividend policy from the current level linked to its confidence in sustainable adjusted operating cash flow growth’. Specifically it was noted that the dividend is supported at the 35/35/35 level, and at $25 CNA is management as confident that the group is sustainable, although further adjustments would be required (i.e. further divestments on top of the £500m guidance).

PM

There it is again

11:31 am
PM

strong investment grade credit rating

BE

I've not had time, incidentally, to take wild stabs in the dark at what consumer-facing business Centrica's planning to buy for about £150m.

BE

Might be the ENI or Viridian assets referred to earlier. Might not. Suggestions welcome.

11:32 am
BE

It's such a moribund market for M&A right now that we'll welcome even the most leftfield speculation.

undefined
PM

Welcome to ML

11:33 am
PM

Why have they done this Africa placing

PM

PM

11:33 am
PM

Jsut to create a bit of work for their bankers?

PM

PM

11:34 am
PM

(Btw -- ahve you noticed how Barc research has reappeared in our inbox?)

BE

(I hadn't.)

PM

(Think they noticed no one was quoting them in the fin press)

11:35 am
PM

(Just macro and commods stuff -- not debt, that was banned under US regs)

PM

Let's see what Trader Gordon has to say

PM

Barclays has completed the placing of 103.6m shares in Barclays Africa (Not Rated) at ZAR126 per share, a 6.5% discount to last night’s close. This reduces its stake to 50.1%, i.e. it is still in a position to offer “strategic control” to any would-be acquirer, with Sir Bob Diamond’s potential interest already formally confirmed. The financial impact is all as expected, i.e. (1) a 0.1% uplift to its CET1 ratio, (2) no material gain on disposal, and (3) modest earnings dilution, pushing the Group even closer to breakeven in 2016e.

11:35 am
PM

So there's no impact to speak of

PM

So why do it?

BE

I don't know.

11:36 am
PM

The placing confirmed today – executed by way of an accelerated bookbuild – reduces Barclays’ stake in Barclays Africa from 62.3% to 50.1%. To a certain extent, the timing/rationale for this partial sale is unclear aside from the fact that it does represent a 20% reduction in a business stake in relation to which regulatory asymmetries render Barclays Group a sub-optimal owner. The sale price represents only a 2.7% premium to the 5-year low seen on 21 Jan 2016.

On the (moderately) positive side, the transaction immediately adds 0.1% to Barclays CET1 capital ratio which, at 31 March 2016, stood at 11.3%. This reflects, we estimate, a £0.3bn increase in the minority interests amount allowed in its consolidated CET1 capital calculation. Even without any further selldown of Barclays Africa, we do concur with Management’s expectation of further appreciation in the CET1 capital ratio during 2016e to, we estimate, 11.6%, (previously 11.5%).

The transaction creates no material gain (or loss) on disposal.

PM

On the negative side, this transaction and, we think, any further partial sell-down, will be moderately earnings dilutive until such time as the released capital can be “redeployed”. Moreover, in the near-term, this argument is somewhat illusory in that the modest amounts of capital-release (pre-deconsolidation) are likely to bolster capital buffers rather than support growth.

Our 2016e EPS forecast falls from 1.3p to 1.0p, i.e. for all practical purposes we see BARC around breakeven while strategic repositioning continues apace.

Barclays PLC (BARC:LSE): Last: 161.60, down 0.85 (-0.52%), High: 164.20, Low: 161.15, Volume: 8.65m
11:37 am
BE

1) The Hotel Chocolat Bond
- Members and customers can invest in multiples of £1,000 up to a maximum of £50,000 for a gross annual return of 7.25%
- The return will be paid in the form of a Hotel Chocolat Card that can be used to pay for products at Hotel Chocolat shops, Cocoa Bar-Cafes and restaurants across the UK as well as online. The Cards can also be used at Hotel Chocolat’s Boucan restaurant and hotel in Saint Lucia
- After three years the Bonds can be redeemed in full or re-invested annually

2) The Tasting Club Bond
- Tasting Club Members can invest either £2,500 or £5,000 for a gross annual return of 7.33%
- The return will be paid in the form of monthly chocolate box selections
- After three years the Bonds can be redeemed in full or re-invested annually

undefined

http://www.investe...1605050700102861X/

11:50 am
BE

BE

Its very expensive sat broadband fleet

BE

Which might be great for long-haul in-flight internet, unless someone figures out a way to connect up normal networks and undercuts them

11:51 am
BE

Which is precisely what's happening, incidentally.

BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

ISAT posted group revenues -3.5% below consensus expectations (-2% below Barclays) and EBITDA -2.1% below consensus (-1% below Inmarsat). Revenues excluding LightSquared/Ligado were -3.7% below with the main culprit being Maritime that is down -4.5% yoy (vs -0.9% in Q4 15 and 0% expected) and Entreprise (-12.6% yoy vs -2.4.% in Q4 and +2% expected). The government was actually higher than feared (+2.8% yoy vs -13.6% in Q4 and -0.8% expected). ISAT blames the poor quarter on short-term headwinds in many markets due to "sustained recession in global maritime and energy markets", as well as the time it takes to "engage" with new customers to upsell them the new product GX Express. As a result, ISAT lowered its 2016 revenue guidance excluding LightSquared from USD1,225-1,300m to USD1,175-1,250m, a -4% cut to the midpoint. This represents a -3% cut vs consensus estimates (Bloomberg) and is in line with our own estimates for 2016. There is no EBITDA or FCF guidance. Separately, ISAT announced a slight revision to the deal with LightSquared that defers part of the payments in the next three years (USD108m, USD111m and USD118m instead of c. USD130m per year). Group mid-term guidance is unchanged.

11:56 am
PM

(Get yer tickets here: https://live.ft.co...estival-of-Finance )

BE

BE

In the meantime, here's Jefferies.

11:56 am
BE

We had been worried by how the deteriorating macro picture would
shakedown in 2016 - those concerns crystallised in a 2016 guidance downgrade
today. The debate will now turn to how confident we can be in the 2018
guidance (which was left untouched). Management has made a decent start to
re-building that confidence, but we think it will take time.
Amber to red: The amber flag raised over the Maritime Enterprise segments in 4Q15
turned red in 1Q16 - Inmarsat delivered a soft 1Q16 print and lowered 2016 guidance (but
left 2018 guidance untouched). Total revenue was -3.5% behind consensus, total EBITDA
-2.2% behind. (Table 1). ISAT has trimmed 2016 guidance by $50m (-4% cut at the midpoint)
to $1,175-1,250m in revenue (ex-Ligado). This won't necessarily lead to a cut to
consensus given pockets of consensus still need to raise Ligado expectations.
2016 guidance: Management cite two reasons for the downgrade: 1. Half the reason is
market conditions in Maritime (more lay-ups scrapping) and Enterprise (shuttering of rigs
less exploration activity); and 2. The other half relates to longer deployment lead times for
GX (bedding in de-bugging type approvals testing) and the elongated procurement
lead time for the US Navy’s CSSC contract (see our preview for more detail). Management
on the call insisted it has been prudent in the guidance downgrade and that trading in
Maritime improved in March and April.

BE

2018 guidance: The debate now turns to whether the market can de-couple the issues
seen in the business today from the medium term growth outlook for the company. The
message on this morning's results call was “yes”; the 2018 guidance is built upon the
revenue visibility from the various ”take-or-pay” agreements (which are un-impacted by the
issues of 1Q16), the visibility from the XpressLink migration (VSAT grew at 15% in 1Q16,
backlog is at its highest point ever) and then the wild card of aviation (also a sector that takes
no read-across from the aforementioned issues in 1Q16). The CEO reiterated the diversity of
revenue roadmaps to 2018 target and (repeatedly) reiterated the latent commercial demand
for GX. There is evident logic in management’s message and we’re inclined to argue that the
2016 guidance trim does not signal an impairment in the core growth story. It is of course
now incumbent upon management to re-build that confidence over the coming weeks and
months – a steady stream of GX contracts wins (something that was again hinted at on the
call) will be the obvious validation for management’s rhetoric.
Ligado: In a (positive, it seems) sidebar to the main guidance debate, Inmarsat has
announced a variation of the Co-op agreement with Ligado, deferring certain payments
form Ligado in exchange for "enhanced spectrum access rights". The message from the call
was that this is a win-win: Ligado gets to "sweat" its working capital harder while it tries to
address the FCC's concerns while Inmarsat gets better revenue surety, avoids the disruption
of having to re-band existing customers and secure its participation in the upside in the
event Ligado gets its house in order.
Other takeaways from the results call: 1. On the CSSC debate, the CEO (rightly in our
view) reiterated that to be relevant long term to the USG, you must be in the Ka-band -
the CFFC contract is part of the 2018 guidance, but is "not particularly material"; 2. The
complementary ground component of the EAN will deploy commercially in 2H17 (first time
we're aware this date has been given "on podium"), DT are progressing well on design and
deployment; 3. China has huge aviation potential - flights per capita are a quarter of that
seen in Europe - the agreement with MCN is an MoU and should turn into a fully fledged
agreement in the next couple of quarters; 4. The Thor-7 contract was opportunistic - no
comment on the economics.

12:00 pm
BE

What RR says: (1) Trading YTD in line with expectations. (2) FY16
outlook (constant FX) is unchanged. (3) EBITA will be “significantly” H2
weighted, with H1 16 “close to breakeven”. (2) FCF will be “significantly”
H2 weighted. (If we take the H1 15 FCF and deduct the yoy drop in EBITA
then we estimate FCF of £-1bn in H1 16). (5) If FX rates for the rest of
2016 stay at the average rate YTD then it would add £50m to FY16
guidance.

BE

 What the bears will say: RR is leaving it all to do in H2 16, with a risk of
missing FY16 guidance.
 The more bullish interpretation: (1) 2016 is about the "law of small
numbers. In 2015 RR generated only 31% of FY EBITA in H1, delivering
£456m of EBITA. RR has already said it faces £550m of yoy headwinds in
Civil Aero in FY16 and that Marine EBITA will drop £75-100m in FY16. If
we assume that the bulk of these headwinds fall in H1 16 then that explains
why H1 16 group EBITA will be close to breakeven. (2) If RR achieves its
FY16 guidance then its H2 performance (EBITA of c£750-800m) will be a
lot stronger than H1, meaning it enters 2017 in better shape. RR always has
an H2 bias to earnings so it would be wrong to double the H2 16 EBITA to
forecast 2017, but the direction of travel would be improving. (3) We have
met many investors (bulls and bears) to discuss RR this year. The bulls
know that 2016-2018 (maybe longer) is a very difficult transition period;
they own RR for the 3-7 year story. We are not sure that these bulls will be
too bothered about the H1/H2 phasing of 2016.
 Valuation: Rolls-Royce currently trades on 2016E/17E P/E of 22.5x/17.5x,
2016E/17E clean P/E of 26.7x/25.5x and 2016E/17E clean EV/EBITA
20.6x/20.4x as at COB May 4, 2016

ENVIRONMENTAL INVESTIGATION AGENCY

12:03 pm
PM

Today over 60 indigenous organizations and NGOs from Peru, Europe, and the United States called for United Cacao Limited SEZC (ticker symbol: CHOC) to be removed from trading on the Alternative Investment Market (AIM) of the London Stock Exchange. As the basis for their demand, the groups cited the company’s breaches of AIM rules and illegal clear-cutting of Peruvian rainforests, claimed and depended upon by Indigenous Peoples for survival. In a sign on letter to the exchange and UK market regulators, groups made clear connections between financing raised on AIM, the London Stock Exchange’s junior market, and at least 11,100 hectares of illegal deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon by United Cacao’s direct subsidiary, Cacao del Peru Norte, and two related companies, Plantaciones de Pucallpa and Plantaciones de Ucayali.

Each of these three Peruvian companies has derived significant financing from the AIM-listed company, United Cacao, which in addition to trading in London, is based offshore in the Cayman Islands, a British Overseas Territory. United Cacao began raising funds in London on AIM in December 2014, despite ongoing Peruvian government actions to sanction its subsidiary, related companies, and their employees for breaking Peruvian laws governing forests and agriculture. United Cacao’s CEO, Dennis Melka, controls a network of at least 25 corporate entities based in Peru.
